He was a black chemist who was concerned about making things affordable, medicines affordable to people who normally hadn't been able to afford things.
His major contribution was to - for Cortisone.
It helped us with rheumatoid arthritis, which was a debilitating - I guess you would call it disease or ailment of that time.
And there were treatments, but at $400 a gram, sterols were not affordable to, you know, poor people or regular working people.
So when he extracted sterols from soybean, it made sterols almost like 20 cents a gram.

You know, when you talk about blacks in history in this country, from the turn of the century during the time that Julian was getting going, we know that there was discrimination in politics, and in the arts, and in sports, and in education, but you don't hear a lot about the racist activity in the world of science, you know?
But apparently that was a big part of what his struggle was because the scientific community, the academy of science did not want to accept him because of his color.
They did not want to accept him.

And a wonderful chemist, Dr. Vitcup(ph)), was the guy who continually prodded the academy to allow Dr. Julian to be a member of that academy, and not until the '70s did he finally accomplish it and have Dr. Julian inducted into the Academy of - National Academy of Sciences.

Obviously he was much more than just this guy that did this sterol thing, because he had been working at Glidden, making paint to dry faster, making faster rising cake mixes, and things that Glidden and people like that were interested in.
He was interested in making a difference in the world in other ways, that people who were like him, and like his grandparents, and people that he knew, people who needed affordable health care.
Well, you mentioned his grandparents, who were slaves in the South, and we talked about how rocky his road to success was.
What was it about Percy Julian that helped him to prevail in the end?

His grandfather, who was caught trying to learn how to write, teach himself how to write, had fingers removed from his hand.
